row.entry: These Rules set out the usual procedures that apply where a receiver is appointed. They permit the court to fix the receiver’s remuneration, require a receiver to provide security and oblige the receiver to file accounts and have them passed. Rule 26.6 contains various powers to sanction a receiver’s non-compliance.
This Part only applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.
The Part is based on the former SCR Part 29. It complements the power conferred by sÂ 67 of the SCA.
Address for service, requirement to provide ‥ [r 26.2]
Appointment of receiver and direction for appointment ‥ [r 26.3.5]
Procedure for the appointment of a receiver ‥ [r 26.3.20]
Proceedings for default against a receiver ‥ [r 26.6.5]
Requirement for written consent to appointment ‥ [r 26.3.25]

p.text: This Part applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court.
Legislation cited in [26.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 67, [SCA sÂ 67.1]–[SCAÂ s 67.5].

This Part complements the power conferred by s 67 of the Supreme Court Act to appoint a receiver whenever it appears “just or convenient to do so”. While the discretion this confers is wide, there are settled principles that guide its exercise. It is highly relevant to the exercise of the discretion whether the property over which the appointment is to be made is already under the control or management of one of the parties. If it is not, then the urgent appointment of a receiver may simply be a matter of necessity to preserve or manage disputed property pending the determination of the proceedings: Owen v Honan (1853) 4 HL Cas 997 at 1032; 10 ER 752Â ; Leney & Sons Ltd v Callingham [1908] 1 KB 79 at 84Â ; Searle v Smales (1855) 25 LTOS 106; Hart v Emelkirk Ltd [1983] 3 All ER 15; [1983] 1 WLR 1289Â . In other cases, where the property is already under appropriate control, particular caution may be required in the exercise of the power — because of the irreversible consequences that may follow to the defendant from the fact of the appointment: Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd (1990) 1 ACSR 445 at 456Â . See R Meagher, D Heydon, M Leeming, Gummow and Lehane's Equity Doctrines and Remedies 4th ed (2002) Ch 28 and [SCA sÂ 67.1]–[SCAÂ s 67.5] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 26.2] r 26.2 Address for service (cf SCR Part 29, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Address for service (cf SCR Part 29, rule 1)

p.text: A receiver must, within 7 days after appointment as such, file a notice specifying an address for service.
No form is prescribed. The ordinary form of appearance may be adapted.
If the court appoints a receiver, the court may give directions for the filing by the receiver of security in accordance with this rule.

If the court directs the appointment of a receiver, then, unless the court orders otherwise, a person must not be appointed receiver under the direction until security has been filed in accordance with this rule.
Subrules (1) and (2) have effect subject to any provision for the time being in force made by or under any Act.

A security to be filed in accordance with this rule must be a security approved by the court that the receiver will account for what he or she receives as receiver and will deal with what he or she receives as the court may direct.
If a security has been filed under this rule, the court may make orders for the vacation of the security.

level.toc-caption: [26.3.5] Appointment of receiver and direction for appointment

heading.title: Appointment of receiver and direction for appointment

p.text: The distinction between rÂ 26.3(1) and (2) involves what may nowadays seem to be an unfamiliar aspect of the practice and procedure relating to the appointment of receivers: Perkes v Landon (NSWSC, Eq 4416/1984, KearneyÂ J, 27 March 1985, unreported, BC8500913). An order under rÂ 26.2(1) effects an immediate appointment of the receiver and, unless the order is expressed to be conditional upon the provision of security, the appointment takes effect from the making of the order: Perkes v Landon, above; McIntyre v Perkes (1988) 15 NSWLR 417Â . An order under rÂ 26.3(2), on the other hand, is merely an order that a receiver be appointed. Such an order, to paraphrase Samuels JA in McIntyre v Perkes, above, is merely prefatory to the appointment and contemplates that the actual appointment will be made after the provision of security: McIntyre v Perkes (1988) 15 NSWLR 417 at 421Â . See also Edwards v Edwards (1876) 2Â ChÂ D 291; Taylor v Eckersley (1876) 2Â ChÂ D 302; Rideout v Fowler [1904] 1 Ch 658Â ; Freeman v Trimble (1906) 6Â SR (NSW) 133.

A receiver will usually be appointed both receiver and manager. A court appointed receiver is an officer of the court and interference with the exercise of the receivers powers and functions may constitute contempt of court: Freeman v Trimble (1906) 6 SR (NSW) 133Â ; Rogers v Commins (1906) 24 WN (NSW) 3Â ; Horne v Leigh (1906) 7 SR (NSW) 51Â .

A party will generally not be appointed as a receiver: Re Lloyd; Allen v Lloyd (1879) 12 Ch D 447 at 451Â . Neither will the appointment generally be made in favour of a person who is closely associated with a party — such as the party’s solicitor, accountant or agent: Hunter v Hunter (1867) 4 WW & A’B (E) 17; Graham v Graham (1872) 3 VR (E) 139; 3 AJR 55; Edgar v Muscovitch (1915) 36 ALT 162. However, the general rule is not inflexible and its application depends upon the property in dispute. For example, in partnership cases one of the partners may be appointed as an interim receiver of the partnership business, on the ground that a partner with knowledge of the business is best able to effectively preserve it while the proceedings are on foot: see Sargent v Read (1876) 1 Ch D 600Â ; Collins v Barker [1893] 1 Ch 578Â ; Cook v Cook [1904] QWN 27Â . Alternatively, an independent receiver may be given leave to employ a partner in the management of the business: Lamerand v Lamerand (No 1) [1962] NSWR 246Â . If the applicant is not aware of a person willing and able to accept the office of receiver, a trustee company or a court official liquidator may be appointed as a receiver.

level.toc-caption: [26.3.20] Procedure for the appointment of a receiver

p.text: Legislation cited in [26.3.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Part 25.

heading.title: Procedure for the appointment of a receiver

p.text: The procedure for obtaining the appointment of a receiver, and the principles that apply, are similar to those that apply to applications for interim injunctions under Part 25 of the UCPR. An applicant must propose a particular person to be appointed as receiver and, where security for the appointment is required, the applicant must also provide security: see r 26.3(2).

level.toc-caption: [26.3.25] Requirement for written consent to appointment

p.text: Legislation cited in [26.3.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 31.15.

heading.title: Requirement for written consent to appointment

p.text: Unless the proposed receiver personally consents in open court, the proposed receiver must provide a signed consent, verified by the affidavit of an attesting witness. No particular form of consent is required. A common form of consent is set out in Precedent 12(8) in Neville & Ashe, Equity Proceedings With Precedents (NSW). See also rÂ 31.15 .
Legislation cited in [26.3.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Form 41.

There is no prescribed UCPR form for security. Security may be given by a deed of guarantee in SCF Form 41 to the Rules. The judge appointing a receiver has a wide discretion as to whether or not to order security. A person appointed as receiver without remuneration will not generally be required to provide security. A person appointed where it is urgent that the receiver act immediately will not usually be required to provide security before the appointment takes effect. A trustee company, and an official liquidator, is usually appointed as receiver without security.
A receiver is to be allowed such remuneration (if any) as may be fixed by the court.

A receiver appointed by the court is entitled to be properly remunerated: Price v Price (1904) 29 VLR 719Â . Provision for remuneration should be made when the receiver is appointed: Westpac Banking Corp v ITS Taxation Services (2004) 22 ACLC 229; [2004] NSWSC 50; BC200400354 at [15]Â ; but may be allowed subsequently: Harris v Sleep [1897] 2Â Ch 80. Normally the receiver looks to the assets to which the appointment relates: Eady v Eady (1895) 16 LR (NSW) Eq 70Â ; Boehm v Goodall [1911] 1Â Ch 155; Rosanove v O'Rourke [1988] 1Â Qd R 171; and is entitled to assert a lien over them: Bernard v Davies (1862) 32 LJ Ch 41 at 43Â ; Re Central Commodities Services Pty Ltd [1984] 1Â NSWLR 25; and a right of indemnity: Shirlaw v Taylor (1991) 31 FCR 222; 102 ALR 551Â . The receiver is entitled to be paid their remuneration in priority to the claims of creditors: Hill v Venning (1979) 4Â ACLR 555; Kerr on Receivers 15th ed p 249; O'Donovan, Company Receivers and Managers p 429; unless the appointment relates to the property encumbered in favour of those creditors: Choudhri v Palta [1994] 1Â BCLC 184; [1992] BCC 787Â .
A receiver must file accounts at such intervals or on such dates as the court may direct.
On the day on which he or she files an account, a receiver must file a notice of motion applying for an order to pass the account.
Unless the court orders otherwise, the receiver must attend on the hearing of the application under subrule (2).
The passing of accounts, and any ancillary directions, is a function normally carried out by either the master or the registrar: Kraft v Kupferwasser (1991) 23 NSWLR 236 at 243CÂ .
If a receiver fails to comply with a requirement of these rules, or of an order or direction of the court:
to file an account or affidavit, or
to attend on the hearing of an application for an order to pass an account, or
to do any other thing,
the court may make such orders and give such directions as the court thinks fit.
Without limiting subrule (1), the orders and directions that may be made or given include orders and directions:
for the discharge of the receiver, and
for the appointment of another receiver, and
for the payment of costs.

Without limiting subrule (1), if a receiver fails to comply with a requirement of these rules, or of an order or direction of the court, to pay into court any sum shown by an account as due from the receiver, the court may charge the receiver with interest on that sum, at the relevant rate set out in rule 36.7(1) or such lesser rate as the court may determine, while that sum is in his or her possession as receiver.
[subr (3) Amendment 32 of 2010 Sch 1[2] effective 1 July 2010]
This rule does not limit the powers of the court as to the enforcement of orders or as to the punishment of contempt.

level.toc-caption: [26.6.5] Proceedings for default against a receiver

heading.title: Proceedings for default against a receiver

p.text: As an officer of the court, a receiver's conduct cannot, without leave, be the subject of proceedings. The proper remedy for a person aggrieved by the receiver's conduct is to apply to the court in the proceedings in which the appointment was made: see Re Maidstone Palace of Varieties: Blair v Maidstone Palace of Varieties [1909] 2Â Ch 283 at 286, applying Aston v Heron (1834) 2Â My & K 390; 39 ER 993; cf Re Hutton; Ex parte Mediterranean Machine Operations Ltd v Haigh [1969] 2Â Ch 201; [1969] 1Â All ER 936. Generally speaking the initiative rests with the parties to bring any default of the receiver to the notice of the court. Any such application should be made by notice of motion in the proceedings.

A receiver is prima facie answerable for all moneys received, and for all moneys that would have been received but for the receiver's negligence or default. The liability exists whether or not the receiver has provided security. See Halsbury's Laws of England 4th ed vol 39 para 918 et seq.

A receiver may be discharged with the consent of the parties. In the absence of consent a receiver must show reasonable cause for an application for discharge. Failing health, incapacity and impossibility of carrying out the receiver's functions, will obviously provide sufficient grounds: Richardson v Ward (1822) 6Â Madd 266; 56 ER 1092.

The court may authorise a receiver to do (either in the name of the receiver or in the name of the parties or any of them, and either generally or in any particular case) any act or thing that the parties or any of them might do if of full age and capacity.
Subrule (1) has effect even if the parties or any of them are not of full age and capacity.
This rule does not limit any power of the court apart from this rule to authorise a receiver to do any act or thing.

In determining what a receiver may be empowered to do regard should be given to the type of orders that are conventionally made in receivership proceedings. This conventional practice is desirable in order to avoid encountering unintended difficulties that might arise in the determination of rights of the parties in relation to the affected property: Kraft v Kupferwasser (1991) 23 NSWLR 236 at 242E–244GÂ .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 26.8] r 26.8 Account on death (cf SCR Part 29, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Account on death (cf SCR Part 29, rule 7)

p.text: If a receiver in any proceedings dies, the court may make such orders as the court thinks fit for the filing and passing of accounts by the representatives of the deceased receiver and for the payment into court of any amount shown to be due.
The court must not make any order under subrule (1) unless notice of motion has been served on the representatives.
A notice of motion under this rule must be served personally.

The rule provides a remedy in the exceptional cases where a defaulting receiver has died. In Seagram v Tuck (1881) 18 Ch D 296Â , orders for account were made against the personal legal representatives of a deceased receiver. Several years after the receiver's death, it was discovered that his formal accounts (which had been passed) were wrong and that the deceased had in fact misappropriated some of the debtor's assets.
